name: International Components for Unicode
description:
ICU is a mature, widely used set of C/C++ and Java libraries providing Unicode and Globalization support for software applications. ICU is widely portable and gives applications the same results on all platforms and between C/C++ and Java software.  ICU is released under a nonrestrictive open source license that is suitable for use with both proprietary software and with other open source or free software.

The Unicode® Consortium has announced that it will host development of the ICU libraries. The ICU Project Management Committee is now a Unicode Technical Committee, the ICU-TC.   For more details, see the [Unicode announcement](http://blog.unicode.org/2016/05/icu-joins-unicode-consortium.html).

Here are a few highlights of the services provided by ICU:

* Code Page Conversion: Convert text data to or from Unicode and nearly any other character set or encoding. ICU's conversion tables are based on charset data collected by IBM over the course of many decades, and is the most complete available anywhere.
* Collation: Compare strings according to the conventions and standards of a particular language, region or country. ICU's collation is based on the Unicode Collation Algorithm plus locale-specific comparison rules from the Common Locale Data Repository, a comprehensive source for this type of data.
* Formatting: Format numbers, dates, times and currency amounts according the conventions of a chosen locale. This includes translating month and day names into the selected language, choosing appropriate abbreviations, ordering fields correctly, etc. This data also comes from the Common Locale Data Repository.
* Time Calculations: Multiple types of calendars are provided beyond the traditional Gregorian calendar. A thorough set of timezone calculation APIs are provided.
* Unicode Support: ICU closely tracks the Unicode standard, providing easy access to all of the many Unicode character properties, Unicode Normalization, Case Folding and other fundamental operations as specified by the Unicode Standard.
* Regular Expression: ICU's regular expressions fully support Unicode while providing very competitive performance.
* Bidi: support for handling text containing a mixture of left to right (English) and right to left (Arabic or Hebrew) data.
* Text Boundaries: Locate the positions of words, sentences, paragraphs within a range of text, or identify locations that would be suitable for line wrapping when displaying the text.

general_comments:
Openki is an interactive web-platform in development with the ambition to facilitate a barrier-free access to education for everyone.
The web-platform is a simple open-source tool for local, self-organized knowledge exchange: As the foundation for mediating non-commercial education opportunities, as the interface between people who embrace themselves for similar subjects and as an instrument, which simplifies the organization of a “peer-to-peer” sharing of knowledge. The platform makes all processes possible from the selection of topics and the organization and execution of courses up to the documentation of the learning material.

test_invocation_justification: The "make test" invocation invokes pytest under the hood.
test_most_justification: Key functionality is exercised through the test suite.
tests_are_added_justification: Enhancements and robustness improvements include changes to the test suite.  https://github.com/git-cola/git-cola/tree/master/test
warnings_justification:
https://github.com/git-cola/git-cola/blob/master/Makefile#L4
We run tests with pytest and checks with pytest and flake8.
warnings_fixed_justification: "make check" is required, and enforced by CI by running tests against new pull requests.
warnings_strict_justification: We are very strict and pass checks on both Python 2 + 3.
know_secure_design_justification: Software is designed in the Unix philosophy with clear separation of concerns.  All "hard" security concerns are handled by Git.
know_common_errors_justification: Author is a Python expert.  The application is written in a safe language and has a limited attack surface, if any.
crypto_published_justification: Git's protocols are well documented and understood.
crypto_floss_justification: Git Cola builds upon Git as a foundation, and reuses its plumbing interfaces.
crypto_keylength_justification: This responsibility is offloaded to Git itself.
crypto_working_justification: This responsibility is offloaded to Git itself.
crypto_pfs_justification: This responsibility is offloaded to Git itself.
crypto_password_storage_justification: No passwords are stored.  The git-credentials subsystem is responsible for this.  This responsibility is offloaded to Git itself.
crypto_random_justification: This responsibility is offloaded to Git itself.
delivery_mitm_justification: Users can securely clone via https://github.com/git-cola/git-cola
delivery_unsigned_justification: N/A we don't make network requests for login / authentication.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No vulnerabilities, but we would fix them right away.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Python -- buffer overflows are not a thing.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Coverage reports are generated from the test suite.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: This is done throughout the test suite.  asserts are used where appropriate, but mostly in the test suite.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: pylint and flake8 errors are addressed immediately.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: This responsibility is offloaded to Git itself.  Git's use of SHA-1 is well understood to not be vulnerable.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: No credentials are stored in any repositories.
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
roles_responsibilities_justification: https://git-cola.github.io/about.html identifies the maintainer.  No other key roles exist.
access_continuity_justification: The git-cola organization has a few members with commit and administrative privileges.  https://github.com/git-cola
bus_factor_justification: A number of contributors have made significant changes over the years.  https://github.com/git-cola/git-cola/graphs/contributors
internationalization_justification: Git Cola has been translated to several languages, and leverages the gettext tools.

test_policy_justification:
ommit 4b2c3ea03277a42ff7d424e634213d15913229e2
Author: Luke Howard <lukeh@padl.com>
Date:   Tue May 21 15:18:16 2019 +1000

    kuser: allow kinit to renew anonymous PKINIT tickets

    Anonymous PKINIT tickets discard the realm information used to locate the
    issuing AS. Store the issuing realm in the credentials cache in order to locate
    a KDC which can renew them.

    (cherry picked from commit d89b5cb966c41015fad524027107dd2d241b44e8)

commit 9793551bb919d0dc6b41d9d6b80356f44d82ac9e
Author: Isaac Boukris <iboukris@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Nov 12 20:08:06 2018 +0200

    kdc: allow checksum of PA-FOR-USER to be HMAC_MD5

    even if tgt used an enctype with a different checksum.

    Per [MS-SFU] 2.2.1 PA-FOR-USER the checksum is always
    HMAC_MD5, and that's what Windows and MIT clients send.

    In heimdal both the client and kdc use instead the
    checksum of the tgt, and therefore work with each other
    but windows and MIT clients fail against heimdal KDC.

    Both Windows and MIT KDC would allow any keyed checksum
    to be used so Heimdal client work fine against it.

    Change Heimdal KDC to allow HMAC_MD5 even for non RC4
    based tgt in order to support per-spec clients.

    Back ported from master, commit:
    b7fe0fb85a780fed3c54ed2539fc974db1884dc2

    Signed-off-by: Isaac Boukris <iboukris@gmail.com>
tests_are_added_justification:

    In heimdal both the client and kdc use instead the
    checksum of the tgt, and therefore work with each other
    but windows and MIT clients fail against heimdal KDC.

    Both Windows and MIT KDC would allow any keyed checksum

    Change Heimdal KDC to allow HMAC_MD5 even for non RC4

    Signed-off-by: Isaac Boukris <iboukris@gmail.com>
know_secure_design_justification: The project leadership each has more than 20 years developing secure software.
crypto_published_justification: The project implements IETF standardized security protocols which were in many cases developed with input from members of the project development team.
crypto_call_justification: Heimdal provides a cryptographic framework that provides its own implementations and can leverage the operating system provided cryptographic implementations, PKCS#11, and OpenSSL.
crypto_floss_justification: open source implementations of all algorithms are provided as a backstop.
crypto_working_justification: weak ciphers are implemented for interoperability as required.
crypto_password_storage_justification: The Kerberos KDC and Kerberos keytabs store keys following industry best practice
crypto_random_justification: operating system and hardware random sources are leveraged whenever possible

delivery_unsigned_justification: SHA1 and SHA256 hashes of the PGP signed tarball are provided via https

enhancement_responses_justification: We usually respond to enhancement requests quickly.

https://github.com/borgbackup/borg/commit/2e1cf17dd5ba5a99185a7a9285bb90a29bb3523f

Soon on project's docs and github frontpage:

https://github.com/borgbackup/borg/
https://borgbackup.readthedocs.io/
vulnerability_report_private_justificati:
https://github.com/borgbackup/borg/commithttps://github.com/borgbackup/borg/commit/2e1cf17dd5ba5a99185a7a9285bb90a29bb3523f

Soon on project's docs and github frontpage:

https://github.com/borgbackup/borg/

build_justification:
it's the usual python way: pip install -e . in the toplevel dir.
that compiles cython / c code and installs everything (into a virtualenv usually).
build_common_tools_justification: pip / setuptools are common tools for python software.
test_most_justification: We measure coverage and although not perfect, it is good.
tests_are_added_justification:
We use https://codecov.io/github/borgbackup/borg?branch=master to continuosly monitor coverage.
Every pull request gets CI testing and coverage measurement.
warnings_justification: we use github CodeQL and flake8 as linter tools.
crypto_call_justification: We use OpenSSL and Python standard library.
crypto_keylength_justification: We use AES256 and HMAC-SHA256, shorter bitlengths are not possible.
crypto_pfs_justification: We do not have key agreement protocol in our code.
crypto_password_storage_justification:
Somehow applies to our keyfile and repokey. It is protected by a passphrase.

Encrypting/decrypting the key with the passphrase involves a random salt, pbkdf2 and AES256.
crypto_random_justification:
We use /dev/urandom for key / seed material.
We use a incrementing counter for AES-CTR mode.
delivery_unsigned_justification:
When encryption is enabled (which is the default mode), we use HMAC-SHA256 signatures.
If the repository is remote, we use ssh for data transmission.
static_analysis_justification:
flake8 python code checker.

it's mostly a style checker, but also identifies problematic code:
http://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/error-codes.html
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: we use github codeql which is advertised like "Discover vulnerabilities across a codebase with CodeQL".
static_analysis_often_justification: stuff runs on github for commits / pull requests.
dynamic_analysis_justification: We have >80% test coverage, but do not use other dynamic analysis tools (yet?).
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Most of our code is Python, but a little is also in C and Cython. We do not use the mentioned tools (yet?).
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification:
https://borgbackup.readthedocs.io/ docs
https://github.com/borgbackup/borg/issues bug reports and feedback
crypto_used_network_justification: We only use ssh for remote repo access.
hardened_site_justification:
X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

Well, we use github and readthedocs.io - we do not have control over their headers. // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification:
We use standard python packaging (pip).

Also, there are 3rd party distribution packages for Linux, *BSD, OS X which use their usual package managers.
build_reproducible_justification: Debian checks for reproducible builds and we fix all issues discovered there.

name: sqlite
description: Embedded SQL database engine
description_good_justification: Top left text at https://www.sqlite.org/ and for more detail under the About menu at https://www.sqlite.org/about.html
interact_justification: Under the "Support" menu on the main menu bar on the homepage.
contribution_justification: https://www.sqlite.org/copyright.html under the "Contributing Code" subheading.
license_location_justification: In the header comment at the top of every source code file, and on the https://www.sqlite.org/copyright.html page of the website.
floss_license_osi_justification: SQLite is in the public domain.  OSI does not approve of that and would rather have a license.
repo_public_justification: https://www.sqlite.org/src
repo_distributed_justification: Fossil is not as common as Git.  But it is widely used.  Actually, Fossil was created specifically to support SQLite development.  All other uses for Fossil are ancillary.
version_unique_justification: Semantic versioning.  Also SHA1 hashes of the source.
version_tags_justification: Tags.  Fossil does tags way better than Git.
report_tracker_justification: The VCS (Fossil) as an issue tracker built-in.
report_archive_justification: Mailing list archives are searchable.  Formal tickets are also searchable at http://www.sqlite.org/src/rptview?rn=1 and http://www.sqlite.org/src/ticket to show but two examples.
test_most_justification: "make test" has in excess of 95% coverage.
static_analysis_justification: We do static analysis.  And we also diss it:  http://www.sqlite.org/testing.html#staticanalysis
static_analysis_often_justification: We do run-time checking with each commit to trunk.
discussion_justification: Mailing list with searchable archives
no_leaked_credentials_justification: There should be an N/A option on this item.
english_justification: All documentation is in English.  Bug reports are via posts to the mailing list.  There is a bug-tracking system that is open for viewing to the general public, but is closed for input.  The bug-tracker used to accept anonymous input, but we closed it due to abuse.  As currently implemented, bugs are reported on the mailing list, then approved developers transfer bugs into the bug-tracking system as needed.
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: Network Block Device
description: This project contains the reference implementation as well as the protocol specification for the Network Block Device (NBD) protocol, first added to Linux in the 2.1 kernel series, now used in other situations too.
description_good_justification: on the main project website -- http://nbd.sourceforge.net/
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>. Issues and pull requests are accepted, but mailing list posts are also.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/yoe/nbd/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: man pages shipped with the software, a README file explains basic usage.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Releases are done through sourceforge. Usually I ship release notes too, although I have sometimes forgotten in the past. For an example, see https://sourceforge.net/projects/nbd/files/nbd/3.14/README.txt/download
release_notes_vulns_justification: CVE identifiers are used in git commits and release notes of releases fixing vulnerabilities.
report_archive_justification: mailinglist, issue tracker (sigh, same url: https://github.com/NetworkBlockDevice/nbd/issues and https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/nbd-commits)
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: private vulnerability reports are not supported
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: no vulnerability reports in over a year. The five reports which existed over the history of the project were publically fixed in about that time.
build_justification: autotools build system available, but configure file is not committed. See https://github.com/yoe/nbd/blob/master/autogen.sh
test_justification: autotools' "make check" runs a variety of test, although we don't test everything atm.
test_most_justification: It doesn't cover everything, but writing tests is complex, and I've not had much time to work on this.
test_policy_justification: It's an informal policy, but I try to write tests as new functionality is added, or request that for patches implementing new functionality.
tests_are_added_justification: https://github.com/NetworkBlockDevice/nbd/commit/b22c01d3d889b2f0eee4b3ec10edeb4cabf6b6bc is an example of a commit that adds a test for one of the recent new features, TLS support.
crypto_published_justification: spec refers to TLS for its cryptography needs, no "own" protocols are invented or used.
crypto_keylength_justification: Defaults to the priority string "NORMAL:-VERS-TLS-ALL:+VERS-TLS1.2:%SERVER_PRECEDENCE", which takes care of this. Priority string is configurable at run time. Spec requires minimum of TLS1.2.
crypto_working_justification: Defaults to the priority string "NORMAL:-VERS-TLS-ALL:+VERS-TLS1.2:%SERVER_PRECEDENCE", which takes care of this. Priority string is configurable at run time. Spec requires minimum of TLS1.2
crypto_password_storage_justification: passwords are not stored anywhere, authentication is only possible with certificates
delivery_mitm_justification: Sourceforge downloads are delivered over https. Additionally, git tags for releases are signed with gpg.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: no current outstanding vulnerabilities. Past vulnerabilities were all fixed within much less than 60 days.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: All known vulnerabilities were fixed ASAP after being reported, and there is no reason to change this.
static_analysis_justification: Project is on Coverity Scan. Additionally, occasionally the clang static analyzer is run.
static_analysis_often_justification: Coverity Scan does not allow to run code analysis daily for a project of this size, but it is run weekly. Commit frequency is usually much lower than that, but is rather bursty, which makes it hard to run on a per-commit basis
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We're not doing dynamic analysis at the moment
crypto_weaknesses_justification: Does not require any specific algorithms except those required by TLS1.2
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests. There's also a mailing list, which is preferred for general discussion.
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
build_reproducible_justification: nbd is part of Debian, and has been tested there to be reproducible: https://tests.reproducible-builds.org/debian/rb-pkg/unstable/amd64/nbd.html
